name: Hostelling International - Los Angeles/Santa Monica

reviews.text: I stayed at the HI Santa Monica for 5 nights in July and had a great time. the location is great, just a block from the beach and pier, and a block from the Thrid Street Promenade. Santa monica and Los Angeles buses are plentiful and close by as well. This hostel is big and has a nice courtyard and large kitchen. They seem to be having a problem with the keycards, you basically have to get them reswiped each time you come in. The staff at times seemed a little unfriendly, I think they are overworked.. it's a very busy hostel. Each Wednesday they have a pubcrawl for $25. It was a great way to meet other travellers.
reviews.title: Fun Hostel, great location

reviews.text: This large hostel is very new. A big foyer with helpful desk staff. Swipe cards for keys, stairs and a lift! Breakfast is included and is great. eggs, cereal, toast, bagels, tea, coffee, juice, fruit.
reviews.title: Excellent Hostel

likes.disliked: — i wish i had of stayed there longer

reviews.text: Rooms have a seperate shower, sink and toilet (what a great idea!!) the room I stayed in had 8 bunks with a terrace. They assign you a bed number and a matching locker number. Free wifi or cheap computers. Huge flat screen tvs and another huge movie room with huge screen. A huge laundry as well.
reviews.title: Great value, great location

reviews.text: This is definatly a great hostel that you can base yourself at with tours running into down town LA area, and very easy to get too and from the airport. Only one street back from the beach and shopping. Excellent location.
reviews.title: Great hostel

reviews.text: Had a fantastic stay here in this hostel. Like no other hostel I've stayed in before! Everything was all so new and looked after, and very secure. Best location in Santa Monica, sandwiched between the main shopping street and the beach - 5min walk to each. Near bus links for the airport and to wider LA. You simply cant get a better location for this kind of money.
reviews.title: Really lovely hostel but staff are mean!

reviews.text: Wanted an inexpensive place to stay in Los Angeles and we both had prior experience with hostels in Europe so booked into the facility in Santa Monica. A private room with twin beds cost $78 per night. We stayed 2. Breakfast free but uninspiring. Choice of corn flakes or fruit loops, fruit was canned fruit cocktail, orange juice was bland. Could purchase for extra money yogurt, pastries, etc. The bath was down the hall, but was adequate. 4 washbowls, toilets, showers in women's room. Room spartan with sheets, blanket, towel provided. Room had beds, bureau, no hooks or closets. Elevatored building could accommodate 228. In good area, easy parking in inexpensive garage across street. Plenty of restaurants and shops. Wouldn't walk on Santa Monica Pier alone at night but otherwise felt safe in area. Hostel showed 2 movies per night, had a library, TV room, fantastic kitchen for those who wanted to prepare their own food, common room with piano. Spoke to travelers from Reunion, Brazil, New Zealand, Japan. Most in hostel were travelers, but a few appeared to be homeless and having them there changed the atmosphere. We were more wary than we might have been otherwise. Noisy at night from returning party goers. Earplugs recommended. Overall an OK experience for 2 senior ladies.
reviews.title: Hostel in Santa Monica (part of Los Angeles), California
good for the price
reviews.text: This place isn't bad at all, especially for the price. It's clean and the staff is relatively helpful. However, you are staying at $30/night hostel, so you need to be prepared for a few things. In particular, there's not a whole lot of privacy, your fellow hostellers might be a little bit strange, and the beds are about as comfortable as sleeping on the floor. However, that said, I didn't want to spend a whole lot and I couldn't find a hotel room in LA for under $100/night, so this wasn't bad at all.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: For a large hostel, this place wasn't too bad. There was a big dining area, TV room and library, and only two blocks from the beach and one from the main shopping / dining area, the Third Street Promenade. However, our private room was quite expensive given that the price didn't include breakfast and the bathroom was big, not very clean and down the corridor. The rooms are also tiny - we stayed in a twin for the first two nights and there was barely room for the (smaller than your average single) beds to fit in, although the double room we moved to for the last two nights was slightly bigger. The room was also near the water fountain and so we would get people talking loudly outside our door all night, as well as the noise from the busy 2nd Street outside. No air con either, so it gets pretty hot. Nonetheless, the rooms and the hostel itself were generally quite clean and the staff was reasonably helpful. However, for about the same price we could have stayed in the air conditioned Best Western or the Sea Shore Motel, which probably would have been more comfortable.
reviews.title: Great location, shame about the small rooms

likes.disliked: — Noise from the street and the tiny twin beds

reviews.title: It's a hostel by the beach!

likes.disliked: — Keycard kept on locking out everyday

reviews.text: This was the very first place I stayed at on my first overseas voyage, and I must say it was a very positive experience. I stayed in a six bed dorm with a shower & the security is excellent, unlike other hostels I have since stayed at. Like some other reviewers, I found that the atmosphere around the place wasn't quite what I expected, considered the location, I would have thought the place would be buzzing at night, but it was actually all pretty quite. I saw a few signs up for some structured activities in the coming weeks, but nothing while i was there. The staff were less friendly/willing to chat than I expected, but did do a good job. But having said all that, this is a $30/night hostel, and if you're just after a clean, cheap, secure place to sleep/stay, this is EXCELLENT
reviews.title: Great, but not quite what I expected

reviews.text: This hostel is similiar to the ones I've stayed at in Seattle and NY. Very dorm like, with some rooms having their own bathrooms (one room for shower, another for toilet; sink is outside). The free breakfast isn't as good as the one in Seattle but it stayed the hunger for a while (coffee was good though). There was a room for others to use their wifi and a corner with internet PCs that accept credit cards or bills. A bit overpriced so I suggest walking down to the Santa Monica Library just a few blocks away. Oh, and the hostel is two blocks from the beach, so anybody who thinks this place is overpriced for a hostel, they're right. But, seriously, you're sleeping in a clean room including a bathroom, with breakfast and a stroll to the beach for $37. Lighten up, people.
reviews.title: Great, Big, Comfy

reviews.text: The hostel is good value for money in a great location. I stayed in a room with a TV and queen-sized bed with my son. The room was clean and neat. Breakfast was included in the price. However, the hostel reception staff were a bit cool and bored, and our room was very noisy (it directly fronted a ventilator shaft which rumbled all night long). Make sure when you book that you ask for a quiet room. Otherwise, take your earplugs!
reviews.title: Budget accommodation in a great location.

likes.liked: — Affordable and close to the beach.
likes.disliked: — The service and the noisy room.

reviews.text: I stayed here on 2 separate weekends in November. I will preface this that I am not a foreigner but I have stayed in hostels in the US and Europe before. I've had a myriad of experiences and try stay at hostels that have some sort of standardization with how they're run. My first weekend was uneventful - meaning no serious problems - except that it was freezing in the hostel rooms at night and I needed at least 2 extra blankets. I stayed in an all-female dorm room with an enclosed bathroom. The second trip that room didn't have bottom bunks available so I was given a different room. It wasn't nearly as nice but the same configuration and same price. There were 3 ladies from Ireland on an around the world trip travelling together and they were nice. We spoke for a bit and because I had been at a conference all day and had checked in after 10pm I was ready for bed. I was preparing to turn in when this older woman entered the room with all her belongings in a plastic bag lined shopping cart. The ones you'd go to the supermarket with or transport laundry. So I tried to give her the benefit of the doubt because I was really tired but I immediately thought - WTF! She was removing things and moving around the room for an hour with no indication that she would settle down. Also she was asking me a lot of personal questions and when I told her I was ready for bed and didn't want to talk she became very belligerent. She would not let me turn off the lights. I went to the front desk and explained to the attendant that I thought they had allowed a homeless/marginalized person to check in - I mean what 'traveller' shows up with their things in a garbage bag after 1130pm! They said they would ask the woman to leave and went to the room. I didn't ask for the woman to be kicked out - I simply requested a new room for myself. 10 minutes later the guy says she could stay. I went back to the room and all hell broke loose with her - racial epithets, rantings and all. Oh - and she threatened to slice my throat for good measure. I had to switch rooms at 1230am and spent an uncomfortable night in a mixed gender room with no enclosed bath. I felt bad for the the three women who had gone out and had left their belongings laying around as well but thought maybe she would be nicer to them. In the morning I went back to the front desk to file a complaint and here's where the added insult to injury occurred. The desk staff was just unresponsive "well what did she do" and "we allow locals to stay" Well, duh! I live in the same state but 400+ miles away, but crazy is crazy. I finally got a manager and was speaking to her but could tell she was just going to blow me off - but the the other 3 women came down to complain as well and we all shared equal groans at the experience and delight that we had 'survived'. They told the manager that the woman had kept them up all night talking to herself and moving around the room. And STILL the management was being difficult. We all said in unison how we did not feel SAFE with her and I think some dim bulb of humanity or common sense must have finally been released and they asked the woman to leave. BUT WHY DID THEY LET HER CHECK IN AT ALL!!! Ok - I'm all for being understanding but I could tell the woman was 90 cents short of a dollar from the get-go!! This is where I start to wonder if they choose making a few extra dollars over the safety and comfort for their guests. There was NO good judgement used in the decision to let that woman check into a hostel where she was sharing a room with other people. She should have stayed in a room by herself. They should have immediately addressed my concerns with an appropriate response. They made the situation worse! I was cranky and exhausted and I could tell the staff had an attitude about the entire incident towards me for 'bothering' them. Had I booked my travel as a package and spent an extra $150 I could've gotten a nice air/hotel deal, but I'm a musician and was trying to be economical. Compared to the first trip at the hostel in the end it just wasn't worth it. The hostel may have an open policy but they are required to provide a minimum amount of safety and I don't think it was unreasonable for me to expect that. I still have not been reimbursed for the price difference [rooms w/o baths cost less] or offered a free night for my inconvenience. No one has apologized either. If the woman had acted on her violent threats they would have been liable.
reviews.title: They Let Homeless/Vagrants/Mental Patients Stay Here

reviews.text: The location of this place is great-on the block between the sea and third st promenade, the main shopping area. There is also a convenient car park over the road, which I was never charged for overnight. The hostel was clean and had a good kitchen, but it just lacked that hostel feel of friendliness and internationality. Rooms were very hot in summer and 4 times I had to trek from the top floor down to the front desk to replace my key card, which liked to stop working. At no time did the grumpy desk staff apologise for this! I would stay here again, for the location, but isn't great when travelling alone.
reviews.title: Great location... shame about the atmosphere

aka: Hostelling International - Los Angeles/Santa Monica Hotel Santa Monica
description: HI-Santa Monica hostel is set close to cafes, restaurants and movie theatres, and is only just two blocks from the beach. The J Paul Getty Center, with its spectacular art, architecture and views, is nearby. The hostel has been fully renovated with a fresh, new look. There is capacity for 260 guests and facilities include daily movies, internet access, kitchen, laundry and breakfast.Enjoy your stay at the Santa Monica hostel with easy access to Hollywood, Beverly Hills, UCLA, Venice, Malibu and downtown Los Angeles. A tour operator services the hostel, with daily excursions to Disneyland Resort, Universal Studios, and all the area's famed attractions. This location is the largest purpose-built hostel in the USA,just nine miles from Los Angeles International Airport (LAX). Come and check out Santa Monica.
